description: Borrowed from Latin subōrnō, from ōrnō.

verbs.description: suborn (third-person singular simple present suborns, present participle suborning, simple past and past participle suborned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To induce to commit an unlawful or malicious act, or to commit perjury [from 16th c.]
examples: Lord Chief Justice Abbott , in delivering their to suborn opinion, observed, that the judges understood that such an assumption had been made in the question put to them.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To procure privately, or by collusion; to incite secretly; to instigate.
examples: The informer Diocleides was hailed as savior of the city, crowned with a wreath, and taken in honor to the Prytaneum where he dined at public expense.  In their excitement and gratitude the Athenians noted neither his attempt to suborn a bribe nor his delay in seeking public safety.
